eta ok in fairness , i reviewed this product yesterday , i was not impressed with the rice at first serving , but today , i opened up the rice container and what hits me in the nose is basmati aroma , why this rice did n't smell like this last evening after cooking is beyond me . i did n't have any other strong cooking orders going on at the time . today the scent was very pleasant . identifiably basmati . i heated a bowl with some siraracha and a sprinkle of parm cheese and other than the rice being slightly underdone and a bit al dente it was pretty good . the flavor had time to develop overnight ( i guess ) and it was pretty good . it did n't have that cardboardy taste this afternoon , so i 'm thinking i need to increase the amount of water slightly and see what that does . i just wished it tasted like it did today last night . we eat a lot of rice in our household , many types from black rice to off the shelf cheapy stuff . this lundberg basmati rice had a lot of green rice and some husks , it was clean though , there was no clouding of the water as i was washing it . i used the recommended amount of water and a bit of butter in my rice cooker . an old style zoji . the rice smelled like brown rice as it cooked , it did n't have the nice scent of basmati at all . when it was done , the rice had stuck to the bottom of the rice pot . something that rarely happens here . the rice tasted like cardboard . not even a hint of basmati flavor that i could discern . even my husband commented that the rice tasted odd . oh well . this product is off my list . we have bought plain old kroger brand brown rice that tasted better than this .

i am not a shake person . initially i got these for my mother who suffered a stroke . she was not taking food but was amenable to shakes . with qqq grams of protein , these seemed ideal . additionally they are low carb with no added sugar . but when her tastes changed , i was left with a case of the frosty chocolate , french vanilla and banana cream . these are certainly palatable . the frosty chocolate has a mild cocoa flavor . i find it better with a bit of added espresso or cocoa powder . torani makes a sugar free raspberry syrup that makes this shake extra decadent . the french vanilla is too sweet for my tastes but is also easily enhanced with the addition of added flavoring . extra vanilla is good , or the torani sugar free syrups easily enhance the taste . the banana cream is also good , again a bit too sweet for my tastes . a touch of lemon or rum extract helps quite a bit . the shakes are best served well chilled and they do hold you . i have had them for breakfast and was surprised that i was not hungry by mid morning . the texture is decent , not chalky or cloying . they also serve well as the base for smoothies . i recommend these shakes . the flavors and textures are good . they provide a generous serving of protein without outrageous amounts of sugars , fats or carbs . excellent as a pre or post workout drink , they can also provide nutrition to the person on the go or someone recovering from an illness .

hibiscus is a bushy annual plant . parts of the flower are used to make a popular drink in egypt called karkade . various parts of the plant are also used to make jams , spices , soups , and sauces . the flowers are used to make medicine . hibiscus is used for treating loss of appetite , colds , heart and nerve diseases , upper respiratory tract pain and swelling ( inflammation ) , fluid retention , stomach irritation , and disorders of circulation ; for dissolving phlegm ; as a gentle laxative ; and as a diuretic to increase urine output . tea companies in china and india use so much chemicals that even usda organic becomes questionable . this has few good things going for it . frontier , the producer is number one . seller is amazon . sells for less than qqq a pound which is a good price . it is cut and sifted . it is the whole flower so you get the petals as well as calyces where i prefer only petals , no calyces but no one sells only petals . it is usda organic . it is not a beautiful shrub otherwise i would plant it which is the best way to get the fresh petals since it is a healthy plant with many medical uses .

i love this scent ! perfumey and potent , i barely use any of these in the wash and they do the trick . the scent is strong so you do n't need much . it do n't really know what to compare the smell to , other than it smells like a feminine perfume ... floral but with a bright citrus note too . on clothing , it 's very mild , but if you are washing a picky male 's laundry you might want to try something more herbal . my husband does n't care one way or the other so this is fine for us . i know fabric softeners / scent boosters / added stuff are not that great for fabrics but i like my laundry to smell clean . i respond to scent and i have found that i enjoy doing laundry much more if i have nicely scented things to use . i was using purex crystals but the packaging is deceptive , it 's only about qqq of the way full . i also have to use more in order to get the benefit of the scent . the downy packaging is a bit better and i do the tiniest sprinkle . one bottle lasts a long time . they open easily ( i guess so people can try the scent before purchasing ) and people can steal right from the bottle . i have found half - empty bottles on the shelf before . a friend of mine works in a department store and she says people will dump the entire contents into a ziploc bag and walk out with it ! so be sure to check your bottles when you make a purchase ! it 's easy to just grab a bottle thinking it 's full and get home to find that some is missing , especially if you 're a distracted mom and are in a hurry to get home before your child has an in - store meltdown ! i have been a huge fan of magic erasers for many years . mr. clean is a marvel , there have been only a couple of times in more than a decade where he failed to do the job i asked him to do . these erasers have been a great help to me and i will never be without them in my home . a few tricks i have learned over the years : qqq . using glass or all - purpose cleaner to damped the area can be better than water if the crud is greasy . qqq . because they crush and darken as they are used , i usually tear off a piece to clean the blackened stuff burned onto the oven or stove then toss that piece into the trash when i am done . that way the remainder of the sponge stays white and clean until i need it for something else . qqq . do not use on vinyl flooring to remove heel marks . it works really well on all other floor surfaces , and actually it also works on vinyl too but it leaves a dull finish wherever it touches . qqq . most things come off quickly & easily . it is better to use a little more time than more pressure on really tough stains . qqq . a final wipe with a damp cloth or paper towel leaves a surface looking like the stain never happened . qqq . i can not tell a difference between the original and the " extra power " version except for the shape . i buy whichever is the better deal .

my doctor recently advised me to switch from my regular creamer to a non - dairy creamer such as coffee - mate , so i was pleased to give this sugar free hazelnut flavor a try . despite being a longtime coffee drinker , this is actually my first time ever trying coffee - mate - or any type of powdered creamer - so i really did not know what to expect . with relatively low expectations , i will say that this was decent , perhaps a little better than i anticipated , especially considering that it is sugar free . it has a powerful hazelnut scent , right out of the shipping box , in fact . hazelnut can be a hit or miss flavor depending on how artificial it tastes . i would say that this is pretty good considering that it is sugar free . most of all , i was pleased with how quickly and effortlessly it dissolved in my coffee . i was expecting something more along the lines of powdered hot chocolate mix that needs to be stirred for quite a while . this works very fast , and a little goes a long way . as it should , because this qqq ounce canister apparently has about fifty - eight servings . which brings me to my biggest criticism , the fat content . i had been using a dairy creamer that had zero grams of saturated and trans fat per one - tablespoon serving . i was a little surprised to find that the exact same amount of sugar - free coffee - mate has qqq saturated . beyond that , the number - one ingredient is hydrogenated vegetable oil ( trans fat ) . apart from the lack of sugar ( only one carb per tablespoon ) , i can not imagine how this is healthier for me than the diary creamer i had been using , so i will definitely ask my doctor about this on a follow - up visit . still , for what this is , as a substitute for diary , it 's a decent sugar - free creamer that delivers a lot of sweet flavor , even if there 's a lot of fat that goes along with it .

the clear shampoo qqq total care is a good two in one shampoo / conditioner . the shampoo is a light pinkish purple and has a soft fruity / floral scent . the scent is not overwhelmingly sweet scented though - the smell is soft and subtle , and not overly feminine . this shampoo lathers up very well with a small amount . i have slightly longer than shoulder length hair and was able to get by with the amount about the size of a quarter . my husband , who has a crew cut , did n't really more than a dime sized amount . the shampoo lathered up well , rinsed out easily , and left my hair feeling very clean . unfortunately , with longer hair , it left my hair feeling almost " too clean " - as if the oils were getting stripped away . i felt that i needed a conditioner when using this shampoo . the husband , on the other hand , loved this shampoo . because of his thick , short hair , he felt that his hair was clean , conditioned , and soft . overall , if you have shorter hair , this would be a great qqq - qqq shampoo to consider . however , those with longer hair may need to get themselves a good conditioner to go with this .

i use vco in the mix for my hair , shaving cream , soap , hand lotion , face lotion , body lotion , tooth paste as well as i make popcorn and consume it straight out of the jar for its nutrients . years ago , i was able to get raw , hand pressed coconut oils from fresh coconuts from mexico produced right here in us but due to popularity of vcos , many producers have been creative in making money by misleading shoppers as well as many misleading reviews by shoppers certainly has hyped the business of vco to another level . extra virgin coconut oil is a lie since extra virgin applies only to olive oil and infact the vco market has become so saturated that many producers are removing extra from their labeling and calling it virgin coconut oil , no more extra virgin . in canada where the best vcos are produced , it is illegal to even use the term , extra virgin for coconut oil but in us the laws are very relaxed . there is no extra virgin coconut oil , only virgin , there is no pure , no # qqq , no qqq % , no premium liquid , or any of those terms used for coconut oils . there is no coconut oil especially produced for beauty product which is any different than for cooking or consumption either as a salad dressing or right out of the jar with a spoon . the higher the grade , the higher the nutrients , everything else are marketing tools to sell coconut oil for more money . refined or unrefined : the decision to choose between refined vs. unrefined is dependent upon the intention or use of the oil . unrefined coconut oil has a smoke point of qqq degrees fahrenheit , whereas , refined coconut oil 's smoke point is qqq degrees fahrenheit making it great for high heat cooking or sautéing . grade a : unfiltered , fair trade , certified organic by the usda , canada organic , bc certified organic , ecocert , first pressed vco and kosher . hand pressed and cold - pressed to produce raw oil from fresh coconuts in as little as two hours . grade b : unfiltered , fair trade , certified organic by the usda , kosher , cold - pressed from fresh coconuts . unknown if first pressed , not ecocert , not raw oil produced in couple hours or less like grade a. grade c : unfiltered , certified organic by the usda , kosher , cold - pressed from fresh coconuts . unknown if first pressed , not fair trade , not ecocert , not raw oil produced in couple hours or less like grade a. grade d : unfiltered , certified organic by the usda , kosher , cold - pressing / expeller pressing . unknown if first pressed , not fair trade , not ecocert , not from fresh coconuts but from copra , not raw oil produced in couple hours or less like grade a. this is grade c vco . i consume grade a and b with a spoon right out of the jar but for popcorn i go with grade c. i do not consume filtered or grade d. when heated , just like any food item , vco loses its nutritional value . as a beauty product , i mix this vco with co since co is one of my favorite oils for my skin and it keeps the vco in liquid form instead of solid form regardless of the temperature . not fair trade , not a extra virgin oil , this is only a three star vco .

my teenage daughter and i have been trying to find an easy , ready to go protein shake that we like . i 'm trying to drop a few pounds and she has a very hectic summer schedule and barely has time to eat most days . she does n't care for most protein bars and does n't want to resort to junk food since she 's trying to make healthier choices as well . this banana cream shake from svelte gets a thumbs up from both of us . it tastes great . i 'll try to describe the taste but i 'm not sure what to compare it to because i 've not had many banana flavored drinks . it has a real banana flavor , not artificial or syrupy , with what tastes like a milk base . it 's not too thick like some shakes . it 's about the consistency of whole milk . it 's not too sweet either . we both love the flavor . the fact that these are organic , have a long shelf life , and do not have to be refrigerated ( although we prefer them cold ) are all added bonuses . these are a little more expensive than some other protein shakes but they really do taste great and are worth it . they did a great job of curbing my appetite and helping my daughter have the energy to get through her busy day . we are definitely ordering more and planning to try these in some of the other flavors as well .

when i first encountered benzalkonium chloride , i was really skeptical . i 've heard rumors of people going blind as an ingredient found in eye contact lens solutions , causing nasal irritations when used as a nasal spray , or causing rashes in skin conditioners like body lotion . i did further research , and turns out that the qqq % of benzalkonium chloride ( used in this babyganics hand sanitizer ) is beyond the safety standards from the national library of medicine which is qqq % ( anything beyond qqq % is considered toxic for your skin , but not enough to kill someone ) . so , i gave it a try , and here are my impressions . i am happy that this does n't contain an overwhelming and annoying alcohol smell ( yay ! it 's alcohol free ) . it 's incredibly soft on my hands , unlike germ x and purell , they severely dry out my hands ( even if they added aloe vera extract ) . the foam reduces the amount of waste compared to the liquid pumps . it does the same job as those chemically derived hand sanitizers . with this extremely mild and moisturizing hand sanitizer , i know it 's meant for babies , but i highly recommend it for people with sensitive skin . i use it at work and school , because it is that wonderful .

i gave myself a short research course on all - purpose and other flours because i had no idea why i preferred king arthur unbleached all - purpose and gold medal . i also did n't know why one would buy bleached flours . i learned that " all - purpose " designates a mix of different flours / hardnesses to create a flour between the hardness of bread flour and the softness of pastry flour , hence the " all - purpose " label . unbleached flour is a little harder than bleached because of the resultant grain texture . i also discovered that king arthur has a higher protein content ( qqq % ) than gold medal which gives it a stronger ( more gluten . ) technically , these two flours should perform differently for me , although i have n't noticed -- yet . i like king arthur for its fine and even texture , and the way it performs in everyday recipes . i can use it in place of bread flour for a softer but still structured crumb in yeast baked goods . the flavor is always fresh . i would recommend a softer flour like white lily for tender baked goods like biscuits or pie crusts , although i 've still used this blend for those items with good results . this is a basic flour blended to be used in a wide variety of recipes . -- debbie lee wesselmann

i 've been eating this and other varieties ( and competing similar products ) as a part of a dietary meal plan , so i thought i 'd share my experience . i 'm not going to focus on nutritional details since that 's readily available on the package . instead i 'm focusing solely on subjective experience , and since i ordered like qqq different kinds i 'm going to use a standard template because i 'm lazy that way . preparation : heating time was accurate ; one minute in a qqq microwave oven on a rotating plate perfectly heated the entree . observations : unlike other entrees i 've been eating , this one has a slightly different presentation . rather than mixing the sauce directly with the pasta , this one has a separate little cup of sauce on the side . after microwaving you pour the sauce onto your pasta , toss the little cup away , mix , and eat . while this may be a bit more wasteful , it does allow barilla to do something that other pasta entrees are unable to do : serve al dente pasta . since the pasta is n't sitting in a pool of sauce for an indefinite period of time , the pasta does n't get that characteristic mushiness that precooked pasta is known for . as a result this pasta is significantly more firm than any other ( non - barilla ) entree , and i wholeheartedly approve of this method . the sauce had a good flavor and was perfectly in proportion to the amount of pasta given . i was n't particularly fond of the heat though ; there was definitely some " spicy " in there , no doubt about it , but it was just spicy with no perceived flavor behind it . not a big fan of heat without flavor , but if you are you might appreciate this one more . verdict : not in my top five , but definitely will be reordering this .

sensodyne is really effective for sensitive teeth . it allows me to drink cold liquids without wincing or jumping out of my skin so i really like all varieties of it . this one , the pronamel one , is n't my favorite but it works well as far as desensitizing . it is n't as fresh tasting as most other varieties and it does n't whiten as well as most of the others . i need that because my teeth are stained from tea drinking . usually sensodyne whitening toothpastes do a great job of removing those stains . this one helps but does n't quite do the job . i ca n't really say whether it has helped save my enamel , which i am losing , but i am sure it is n't hurting it . i am happy with this toothpaste for desensitizing and for general cleaning of my teeth . it is fresh enough that i do n't need mouthwash but i prefer a stronger flavor . if it actually helps save my enamel , i will happily give up the whitening and use activated charcoal to do that part ( which i do use anyway ) . i will have to see what my dentist says when i go back as far as how my enamel is holding up . i ca n't actually see any specific changes in my enamel but it is gentle . great for people with sensitive teeth who also are concerned with enamel loss . not as great for those who want superior whitening or a really bold , fresh flavor . still , you ca n't beat the brand for really helping to make sensitive teeth more bearable , no matter what variety you choose .

like the wand itself ( which you 'll need to use these refills the way they are intended ) , these refills were on sale with prime pantry so i thought i 'd try them . i should state that i normally use seventh generation toilet bowl cleaner ( and a regular brush ) , so this product was quite a departure from what i 'm used to , but i figured i would give it a try and maybe use it for quick cleaning when i was in a hurry . in short , i am not impressed with this product -- the wand or the " sponges " ( these refills , a few of which come with the original wand ) , and here are my reasons why . first , the disposable " sponge " you attach to the handle is very small . this is adequate for cleaning the bowl where there is no water ( and i think it works decently under the rim , unlike some other reviewers , though a brush can do more ) and should work well for most of the bowl if you manage to mostly drain it first , though you need some water to " activate " the cleaning product on the sponge . however , seems too small and perhaps not abrasive enough to adequately clean near the " drain " area at the bottom of the bowl , which is where i find hard water deposits . it also works poorly to remove the hard water deposits at the top of the water line in the bowl , even if i try to let the cleaner soak in the bowl for a while . second , the cleaning product built into these sponges is apparently dyed blue , which darkens the water to such an extent that it 's hard to see what you 're doing in the bowl and whether your efforts to clean are actually making a difference . third , the cleaner is very bubbly , which also makes it hard to see what you 're doing ( i know , i know , people think that bubbles mean that it 's working , but other products i use bubble less and still clean effectively ) . finally , i do n't think germaphobes will appreciate this product as much as they think they will : because the sponge is so small , some of the handle will have to get dipped in the water in order for you to clean , especially at the bottom of the bowl -- although i guess the handle is easier to clean than a brush . ( just make sure it 's dry before you put it back in the holder or it will drip onto the floor . personally , i spray the handle with a disinfecting spray and let it dry before i place it back . ) in the future , i will stick with my other cleaning products . the " natural " cleaners i 've used clean just as well , if not better , and i find a traditional brush more effective at cleaning and easier to use .

i 've kept a bottle of tabasco ( the original blend ) in my kitchen for more decades than i care to admit . i 've added a few drops to any number of dishes that i wanted to " kick up " a notch and used it regularly in a bloody / virgin mary . i 'm embarrassed to say i never experimented with any other brand of hot sauce until recently . after purchasing and taste testing over qqq different hot sauces ( everyone needs a hobby ) , writing up notes , test tasting them blind again - writing up new notes and then comparing my old versus new notes ----- i have to say tabasco 's original blend turns out to be one of the worse hot sauces i have tested . tabasco 's original has only two tastes : hot peppers combined with a very heavy dose of vinegar . the bitter vinegar after - taste , so typical in tabasco 's original , is not an inherent quality of a good hot sauce . i could provide an extensive list of hot sauces that are far superior to tabasco 's original but here are just a few that are widely available : i encourage you to try any or all of them . i 'm very certain you will be pleasantly surprised . qqq ) huy fong sriracha hot chili sauce ( as potent as tabasco ) but with far less vinegar with a hint of sugar and garlic . available in most supermarkets . praised in many reviews and rightly so . look for a large bottle with a rooster on the label . qqq ) cholula hot sauce ( milder and less vinegar ) - often highly rated by professional reviewers and available in most supermarkets . look for the wooden top . qqq ) tabasco 's own chipotle blend ( much milder - rich tasting ) featuring the chipotle smoked pepper -less vinegar - widely available i hope i 've encouraged you to try a few other hot sauces . ps : once you get away from tabasco 's ( original ) hot sauce and what i find to be its excessive vinegar after - taste you open up a whole new world . there are so many superior hot sauces available that it is almost hard to comprehend . things have certainly improved since the late qqq when tabasco first came to market . while tabasco likes to brag that this is their original blend ---- that is not a " plus " in my view but rather a " minus " - a marketing gimmick where they argue that an inherent flaw ( a lot of vinegar ) is an attribute . btw : less anyone think i have an axe to grind with tabasco - see my review of tabasco 's chipotle hot sauce which i rated as excellent ! what more can i say - experiment - i sincerely doubt you will stick with tabasco 's original hot sauce . update ( august qqq ): while my review was written over a year before - just recently ( august , qqq ) america 's test kitchen , a show on pbs , tested hot sauces . what sauce came in very last ? tabasco ! what was first ? huy fong sriracha . i 'll admit it is nice to have a professional tasting panel come to the very same conclusions i arrived at a year earlier . tastes vary of course

this is an excellent quality , unbleached organic flour that is free of bromate / bromine / bromide . i use it in my bread machine ( i do add some vital wheat gluten and a couple of drops of lugol 's qqq % iodine to improve the finished texture , but it is n't necessary ) . almost all commercial flours have added bromide ; this does not and that , in my book , is a huge health plus . to be brief , bromide is a halogen that competes with your thyroid 's ability to uptake sufficient iodine for your metabolism to work at its peak . before the qqq 's , commercial bread & bakery goods were baked using iodine as a dough conditioner , instead , but , for whatever reason , bromide is now used . hypothyroidism ( or , rather , what i 'd call " subclinical hypothyroidism " ) is rampant in america , and in my opinion , bromate used as a food additive is partially to blame . i 'd recommend health - conscious people google " bromated vegetable oil , " " bromide , " " bromate , " and " iodine " to learn more . this flour is unavailable in my local area & i 'm so glad to be able to get it via amazon 's new prime pantry grocery delivery service . the price is reasonable and this makes a truly delicious loaf of fresh - baked bread . highly recommended !

several years ago , i went on a tour of the celestial seasonings tea factory in boulder , colorado . the guide showed us the bales of tea as they arrived , machines that ground and mixed the tea , and a machine that put the tea in tea bags . the tour included a visit to the room where the peppermint tea was stored . our guide told us that peppermint was stored separately so that it would not contaminate the other teas . he did not tell us what was to come . the doorway into the peppermint room was surrounded by bright red stripes . this should have served as a warning to us . we all innocently strolled into the peppermint room . the smell of peppermint was overpowering . it entered my nose , my head , my lungs , and then my whole being was infused with peppermint . what a rush ! the crowd stampeded out of the room in a hurry . for the rest of the day and into the next , all i could smell and taste was the mint . i am now addicted to celestial seasonings peppermint tea . every time i have some , i am reminded of that fateful day in boulder . the events of that day have changed my life forever . amazingly , the tea is still legal , openly sold in stores and on the internet . i think that the tea is great , but then again i am not an unbiased observer . on your next visit to boulder , take the tour . or go a safer route ; buy the tea from amazon .

i 'm seriously allergic to soy and finding peanut butter without soy has been surprisingly difficult . most common brands add soy and a lot of the supposed organic brands do as well - this is entirely unnecessary , soy is considered one of the top eight most serious food allergies , like milk and shellfish . so far , peter pan has been reliably safe for me to eat and tastes great , but i am glad to find this skippy natural is soy free and provides another option . my initial impression is very good . the peanut butter is creamy and smells good as soon as the jar is opened and there 's no oily skin on the surface . it spreads easily on a slice of bread like it should . the flavor is good - peanutty with a little sweetness , but no burned or scorched aftertaste . it makes a perfectly fine sandwich with grape jelly . the ingredients comparison between this skippy and peter pan are pretty simple as well . personally , i could care less about the type of oil because the absence of soy is a life threatening issue . though the use of palm oil is absolutely not ecologically friendly and is the number one reason for destruction of the asian rain forests . skippy : roasted peanuts , sugar , palm oil , salt . peter pan : roasted peanuts , sugar , less than qqq oils ( rapeseed and cottonseed ) , salt .

why is it that little kids always want a band - aid for every single little boo - boo ? i used to keep them in the bathroom , within reach of the children . they were allowed to freely apply them . big mistake . i got so tired of always running out , of finding wrappers all over the bathroom floor , and discovering used band - aids shoved between couch cushions that i knew something had to change . i 'm now kind of a scrooge when it comes to band - aids . i 've mostly trained my children to believe that any injury can be instantly healed by washing it with soap and water , and putting a kiss on it . however , i do still allow the occasional band - aid to be applied when the skin is broken . our rule has become " no blood . no band - aid . " i have stopped purchasing the expensive band - aids with fun cartoon characters that encourage children to wear them as fashion accessories , and instead buy the boring plain ones in bulk . i ca n't save my children from every little hurt , but i can save a little cash and hopefully a little bit of my sanity .

i was not sure what to expect . soft drinks are not a daily indulgence , but once or month or so we enjoy a take - out pizza and there is something to be said about an ice - cold brown bubbly accompaniment to a hot bubbly cheesy pie ! typically i would go for a coke zero , and on rare occasion diet coke ( visiting family and that is the only option ) . coke life is somewhere in between the two . according to my taste perception , coke zero is more similar to the real thing than coke life . but i am not sure that coke life is trying to be coke . honestly , i am not sure where this product falls in the brand 's lineup . it is not sugary - sweet . i think of pepsi as a more sweet drink , then the original coke . so this would be a step down in the sweet taste chart pepsi - coke original - coke life . it is has a more dry or " aged " ( for you refined beverage consumers ) taste to it . not to say that it is dry . it is a different experience . if you had never tasted coke then you would likely think it is a fine drink . as you have likely tasted coke your brain will go into compare mode . but once you are done comparing you will find the same result - it is a fine drink .

these are really small , much smaller than i expected , about qqq " by qqq " , but the flavor is good and they are big enough to satisfy a craving .. there is actually very little caramel on them , just a very narrow and very shallow stripe down the middle and not enough to taste any " salted " flavor . the cake is very crumbly , a little on the dry side , and not at all cheesecake like but the flavor is somewhat reminiscent of cheesecake . there is a very thin layer of " crust " on the bottom that i really do n't differentiate the flavor of from the rest of the bar . i really like that it 's not so overly sweet . some things are cloyingly so and really make it hard for someone like myself , who does n't eat a lot of sweets , to choke them down , but not so with this . it 's just sweet enough . that may be why the caramel is sparse . overall , if it had been called anything other than " cheesecake " i may have liked it even more . take that expectation out of the equation and they are actually very tasty . they are just qqq calories but keep in mind that more than a third of those are from fat ... qqq grams , qqq calories are from fat . they have qqq grams of carbs , qqq are fiber and qqq are from sugar . a nice surprise of qqq grams of protein per bar . i had my teenage daughter 's boyfriend , a bonafide cheesecake fanatic , taste them and give me his opinion . he said pretty much the same ... good little bar but not really very cheesecake tasting . i would still purchase them again for the taste and qualities and just ignore the label .

a while back i was given the chance to try happy belly 's raw almonds and they were terrific . happy belly 's nuts come in big bags , and i still have some left . having enjoyed those so much , i was interested to see how they are roasted and salted almonds compared . like their raw almonds , these are from california . i typically do n't like salted nuts , in part because they sometimes seem overly greasy from the oil . i was hesitate actually to try these because of that . vegetable oil is the second ingredient listed , followed by sea salt . i have to say that these were probably some of the driest salted nuts i 've had . they were not slick or greasy , which was a big plus for me . as for the salt , i noticed quite a lot of it had accumulated at the bottom of the qqq pound bag . the nuts were salty , yes , and i definitely prefer the raw almonds . but the saltiness was not overpowering , and i know i 'll definitely work my way through this bag as well . a one - fourth cup serving , of which there are qqq in this bag , delivers six grams of protein , four grams of dietary fiber , and only one gram of saturated fat . almonds are about the best nuts out there . sodium is moderate : qqq mg for a fourth cup . not bad as long as one does n't eat too many at one time . overall , i liked these and the overall happy belly selection of nuts from what i 've tried .

organic onion powder made simply from dehydrated organic onions and nothing else . no additives or anti - caking agents and it is non - irradiated . the powder is quite fine , and the flavor is pure . the two ounce jar has a lid that flips open on two sides . one side reveals a half - moon opening so a measuring spoon may be inserted . the other side has a three - hole opening so the powder may be sprinkled . although i usually use fresh onions in cooking , i keep onion powder on - hand because in some applications it is a better choice . it is particularly useful where texture is an issue . for some dishes , like creamy appetizers or deviled eggs produced using a decorator bag and tip , i want an absolutely smooth result . and , sometimes using fresh onions may add additional liquid that will adversely affect the recipe . also since the taste of fresh onions can greatly vary in strength , using onion powder offers greater control and a more consistent result . i regularly use it as an important component in flour dredges for frying chicken , shrimp and vegetables along with including it in dry rubs and various spice mixes ( taco , cajun , italian , etc . ) i use it as part of the seasoning for homemade croutons and it works well in dips , meatballs , soups , marinades and sauces . the onion powder is self - stable with a best by date on the bottle i received qqq months in the future , although this will vary .

according to consumer reports , rice grown in california has the lowest levels of arsenic , however brown rice has the highest levels of arsenic because of the higher concentrations in the bran or the rice . my family eats a lot of rice and the more i read about arsenic levels in rice the more concerned i became and i was happy to find out that there is rice available from areas that are fairly reliable when it comes to lower arsenic levels , but i remain concerned about the levels in all brown rices . lundberg brown basmati rice has always been very tasty and aromatic but we will eat less of it , while i wait for more research to come out about the harmful effects of higher arsenic levels vs the benefits of brown over white rice . lundberg more than any other rice grower has responded with concern and is doing their own research into lowering arsenic levels in the rice , which i appreciate as a consumer . i 'm still giving this qqq stars because it is superior over other brands . edit : i should mention that according to consumer reports lundberg 's brown rice has lower levels of arsenic than many other brands of white rice .

i ate kettle chips for years , then stopped , and now have gone back to them having found the flavors that work for me . i liked the new york cheddar but found them a bit sickening after a while then my interest was sparked again with their salt and pepper flavor and now i ve been working my way through the newer flavors . the roasted garlic is my current favorite . its a good thing for me to have intensely flavored potato chips ( as long as the ingredients are identifiable as real food ) as ill eat fewer of them compared to your more everyday plain potato chips . the only caveat is that if you eat too many roasted garlic chips late at night on an empty stomach , you may end up lying awake for hours , being chased around your bedroom by a huge garlic bulb ( ok , perhaps i was dreaming ) . the red curry is also well worth trying ; the dill pickle and backyard bbq were interesting at first but not outstanding for me . i m giving kettle foods qqq green stars for social and environmental impact . they use qqq % green energy ( either on - site solar and wind or through credits ) ; convert all of their waste oil to biodiesel ; had the first leed gold certified ( i.e. sustainable ) manufacturing plant in the u.s. ; support various causes from wetland conservation to hunger relief . the last frontier that kettle needs to reach is sustainable packaging . i m tempted to give them only qqq green stars because their packaging is non - recyclable and non - compostable . after all , sun chips ( a subsidiary of pepsico , for goodness sake ! ) introduced a compostable bag back in qqq . the bag turned out to be hilariously loud but they improved the packaging to make it quieter in qqq . boulder canyon , who make really tasty chips , introduced a better compostable bag made from wood pulp . recently , oceans halo began selling seaweed chips ( which are interesting ) in nice compostable bags , also made from wood pulp . so why ca nt you , kettle ? hmm ? until you do , i m tempted to curb my cravings for fried potato by making them at home slice , par boil for qqq min , pan fry in olive oil for qqq min , season . hey presto ! until kettle come up with a compostable bag ( please do this soon ! ) there is another option you can recycle your chip bags by collecting a bunch and sending them to terracycle ( postage paid by them ) .

these are not the best beef snack you can buy , but it sure is a bargain . i actually like good beef jerky better . but a look around amazon tells me that somewhere along the line they must have begun including a chunk of uranium in every package . for it sure has gotten expensive . the sticks are like slim jims , only fatter around and a little greasier . but not so much that they should upset ones stomach , or stain your hands like pepperoni . the taste of them is very good , no smokiness , but just the right amount of salt and pepper added . for someone who loves beef , and or all manner of beef snacks , these really satisfy a craving without breaking your wallet . they really are a bargain compared to many beef snacks on amazon . also , though some other reviewers have spoken of boiling them , baking them to get rid of some of the grease , etc , there is no such doings going on here . these may be greasier than jerky , but far from needing any tending too that way in my opinion . right out of the container and enjoy is the way it is around here ... in conclusion , there has been some talk about the way these are packaged . each container comes with two packs with about qqq sticks each . once opened they ca n't be resealed . but that is no concern of mine . one being that unless you are going to have these hanging around for a week or more , the container itself is tight enough for me to keep them fresh . ( and trust me , one container never makes it a week here ) . also , it would be a real pain to have to tear open one of those tight sleeves that sticks like this in the stores come in every time you want one . i prefer them being loose . all in all a darn good and tasty stick of beef that may be a little greasier than most , but well worth the price they are asking ... recommended .. : )

we 've used flush wipes in our household since my kids were little , and i 've probably bought every brand out there . there are small differences between the wipes in various brands --- scent , size , thickness --- but generally they all " work " fine in my experience . i recently replaced all my dispensers with this product because of one superficial reason : the tub is the best . this container is completely white once you remove the outer plastic . no labels to peel off ( and no gummy residue once you have ) , no colors , nothing . the top of the lid has an embossed floral design with the scott 's logo at the bottom right ; this gives the tub a less clinical look without shouting out the brand in a fit of marketing . opening the top lid , you will see that the wipes dispense from a small slit , like tissues . this keeps the wipes from drying out and also prevents my kids from grabbing a handful of wipes at once and clogging the toilet . the wipes themselves have a fresh scent --- i would say " soapy " and not " flowery"---and they have n't caused any issues for the sensitive - skin member of the family . they are alcohol- and dye - free , but have other chemicals of course ; the natural claim seems to be more about the fact that the wipes are made from fibers of sustainable materials .

this is a tasty product but it is not what i am used to when it comes to adobo seasoning . the pepper included in the mix is black pepper . there is no chili powder or any other mexican - based pepper powder , which may just be a regional thing , but that is what i expect to find . and , instead of cumin , turmeric is substituted providing a bit of yellow color but little flavor . this is a close match to the goya brand offering , and it is completely on me that i failed to check the ingredient label before ordering this brand . the first ingredient is salt , which not unexpectedly , is also the first thing i taste the level is qqq mg per qqq teaspoon . next is garlic , black pepper , tricalcium phosphate for anti - caking , oregano and turmeric . it is a good general seasoning and works well sprinkled in scrambled and deviled eggs , on cottage cheese and on various meats whether baked , grilled or broiled . it would also be excellent in meatballs or meatloaf . the quantity provided is generous ( qqq ounces ) and the cost is modest , although none of the ingredients are expensive . this adobo seasoning is also available in a variety that does not include black pepper , but a reduced or salt - free option might be a good idea . in the future , if i want a spice combination like this one i will simply mix it myself so i can control the flavors and salt level .

i have bought this litter several times . it does mask the odor somewhat and does clump very well . all that said i gave it only two stars because , it is n't any where near trackless . as a matter of fact it tracks every where but i did n't notice it right away . so why not ? because it 's basically just scented sand . so the sand scatters and collects down into the carpeting . i vacuum two to three times a week for cat hair and use a bagged vacuum so i did n't see it in the canister . i noticed it was sandy when i swept up near the litter box and again , well that happens with all litter when the cat steps out . but one day when i was barefoot i noticed this grit in my carpet way out in the living room that i had vacuumed two days before .. i swept it up with a brush and yep it was the cat litter . i checked every room and it was the same . any where the cat walked it was like she had spent a day at the beach . it also collects between her toes and sticks to the sides of the box much more so than other litters . i have used clump and seal since they first came out with it but i honestly think they 've changed it ... or i never realized how much the sand would scatter so badly . i would rather deal with less clean up so sigh ... back to square one in search of the perfect litter . now if you want

i find it amazing that it took me a long time to discover the wonders of ponds . i do not wear makeup often . but when i do , i prefer to use ponds . everything comes out into a damp washcloth . a few times when i 've overdone the eye area , i 've had to do a second application but it is not often . it works perfectly well and it moisturizes as well ! perfect during dry winters . i do occasionally use another face wash , but my go to is this product . i do n't believe i have any clogged pores or unsightly blemishes . as a mom i found another use : it will remove those tattoos kids get . you know the kind you apply with water ? all you have to do i dab a good coat of ponds , wait a few minutes for it to do its magic and wipe it off ( ok depending on the quality of the tattoo and how many your kid got maybe rub a little ? ) but it works better than anything else i 've tried . you may need to re - apply . this has a very slight fragrance . enough that if i had my eyes closed i 'd recognize it as ponds . but it is n't a perfume . the jar says it is hypoallergenic and suitable for sensitive skin . all i can say is that neither i nor my children have had a reaction to this . although i really only use it on my kids for the aforementioned tattoos or when they 've had makeup on ( rather when my daughter got a hold of a lipstick ... ) . so i am not sure about children and long term use .

my family eats a lot of different breakfast / cereal / protein bars , some of which are pretty indistinguishable from a standard candy bar in terms of taste . this breakfast biscuit will definitely not be confused with a candy bar --- it is more like something that might be handed out to prisoners , or starving children in struggling countries . flat , plain , and tan , with a texture like particle board : these biscuits look like a dog treat . i am giving these qqq stars for one reason : they serve their purpose as an " emergency " food , when your stomach is so empty your belly is sticking to your backbone and there 's no chance of a real meal in the foreseeable future . one packet of qqq biscuits has qqq calories , with qqq carbs expanding in your gut to give you a full feeling . keep a package of these in your car 's glove compartment , an office drawer , or a gym locker . it 's pretty hard to chow down all qqq biscuits , though , and do n't even attempt to do so without a large beverage nearby . if you subscribe to the " eat to live " mantra , then these biscuits will be an easy breakfast or snack for you ; if you are more " live to eat " then you will want to look elsewhere .

though i generally prefer darker roasts , i was happy to have the opportunity to try this . the problem for me was that the grind was wrong : i use an espresso maker , or a melitta filter . this was ground for an automatic coffee maker , and thus too coarse to produce flavorful coffee in either the espresso maker ( non - starter ; it was just too coarse ) or the melitta filter . rather than regrind it ( not a good idea ) , i used it for cold brew . though i had to use a lot of it get decent iced coffee , when i did use a lot of it , i did get decent cold brew . because we are ( i hope ! ) headed into fall , and because i need either whole beans or a finer grind to make ( what i regard as ) good hot coffee , this is probably not a variety i will get again . i also think that a darker variety or a finer grind makes better cold coffee . but using a lot of it does , indeed , make satisfactory cold brew .

the reason i like this body scrub is because the beads are smooth but mildly abrasive creating a product that is effective at removing dead skin cells . and , although rougher scrubs made from things like crushed apricot shells may be more natural and environmentally friendly , the jagged bits may create tiny tears in the skin which may result in micro - scarring and possible bacterial intrusion . hopefully , something new will be developed that works as well but is also safe for the planet . the scent is one of those generic fragrances reminiscent of fabric softener , is light enough that it dissipates quickly and seems perfectly appropriate for either gender . daily , i am using the product on areas that tend to have more rough patches like feet , elbows , knees , etc . and two or three times a week i use it in place of a normal body wash . applying it with a wash cloth seems to have the most noticeable effect , than my usual bath pouf which seems to somehow hold a portion of the beads away from the skin , like they are caught in the fibers , so the result is less apparent , less intense . i have experienced no skin irritations from the product . and , i appreciate finding it at prime pantry because lately i have had trouble finding it locally . this is a large tube and compared to higher - end products , reasonably priced .

for most of my clothing , i prefer to use seventh generation or something similarly eco - friendly , bio - based , and free of the synthetic fragrances and stuff you 'll find in most detergents . however , when it comes to gym clothing , you occasionally need something a bit stronger . for those things , i use tide + frebreze for the first wash and then send it back through with no detergent to get rid of any detergent that might be lingering on the fabric . the main reason i do that is because i 've found that the clothing still smells pretty heavily of tide when it comes out , and i 'm pretty sure some breakouts i had for a while were related to this detergent . they only occurred where the clothing washed in this detergent had touched , and they stopped when i started sending things through for a second rinse . so in short , i 'm not crazy about this detergent and it seems to make my skin unhappy - but it does a great job of removing weird smells from clothing you or someone else has worked out in .

this mr. clean cleaning pad was definitely not a truly ` magic eraser ` ( although it has good uses ) nor ` extra durable . i ordered the qqq count pack to have around the house for tough stains , as many people highly recommended the magic eraser products . i usually use more environmentally friendly cleaning products , which sometimes do not have the cleaning power for tough stains / dirt . these pads do clean , but they perform as well as my environmentally friendly cleaning products ; the cleaning performance is lower then all - purpose bleach spray . it 's great i need only water , but i need more performance , not just practicality . - > i used them in the shower and bathtub ( they 're quite practical , as i can scrub while i wait for my conditioner to sync in the hair ) ; the pads clean regular scum , but they do n't remove tough stains and mildew no matter how hard i scrub . - > i used it to remove ( very successfully ) marks from walls and label ink imprinted on my kitchen counter tops . this was the only use i found this sponge to be ` magic ` . - > i used to clean the oven and stove top and it did a decent job of removing grease and burned residues . it still required scrubbing ( which destroys the sponge in one use ) and it 's not more effective than normal cleaning products . in one of the pictures you can see how ` durable ` the pads are . my first use was to scrub the shower / bathtub and the pad started to deteriorate immediately ; it tear apart a littler and the material started to pile . if this is qqq stronger , i guess the normal magic eraser will disintegrate with just one use . and if they are meant for just one time use ... it 's not a cost efficient product .

this is my second bag of happy bellybwhole bean coffee , and i think i am more impressed with this bag than the last . i received a medium dark espresso roast which promised " notes of brown sugar , baking chocolate , molasses , carmel , and toffee . " the dark chocolate flavor was prevalent , and it had the same slightly smokey finish that i experienced with my last happy belly bag , which was also a medium dark roast . i was very pleased to see that this qqq and ounce bag arrived with a prominent sticker informing me of the roasting date , august qqq , and a best before date : january qqq . i do not remember my last bag having that information , and it is certainly good to see it here . honestly , i tend to prefer single origin roasts , which this is not , but i applaud the cultivation of small - scale farmers in the americans , and i 'll be the first to admit a personal preference for the slight acidicity i detect from volcanic or tropical soils . i have a miele system that grinds and brews at a one - touch . thus , i tried this in both a standard coffee brew and an espresso brew . the espresso was richer , more chocolatey , though the regular old cup of coffee was just fine . this is billed as an " espresso roast , " but it need not be used exclusively for espresso . in fact , i think you get a more well - rounded flavor when brewed for coffee . all in all , my second outing with the happy belly brand was an overall pleasant experience . it is comparable , in my opinion , to gevalia , which is one of my favorite store brands . i would get this again , though i might next time go for a slightly less smoky medium roast .

i have sensitive skin that is always irritated when i wear sunblock or sunscreen on my face , so i am very reluctant to wear facial moisturizer with spf in it . with the realities of the problems caused by sun exposure , however , wearing spf on a daily basis is something i have to accept . the problem is , i have tried many different brands of daytime facial moisturizer containing spf , and all have failed miserably . they usually irritate my skin by causing it to sting and become red in spots , as well as irritate my eyes if even a tiny bit gets anywhere near by eyes . from pricy luxury brands to drugstore brands , i have n't found one that i can use consistently yet . when i saw this daily moisture cream with spf from olay for sensitive skin on amazon , it had a $ qqq off coupon , making the price less than $ qqq , so too good to pass up . i have used this moisture cream for a couple of weeks now , and so far it is working better than most i have tried , although it is far from perfect . it is a thick cream that is very opaque in the jar , and i was afraid it would n't rub into my skin well . when applied , it is very thickly white and appears like actual sunblock . surprisingly , it disappeared well into my skin after a couple of minutes of rubbing it in , and did n't leave the zinc oxide look i was afraid of . so far i think it must protect from the sun pretty well , because i have spend several days outside all day wearing this cream , as well as daily life being in and outside off and on , and have n't had any burns or even pinkish splotches from the sun . i have been very careful not to get it anywhere near my eyes , and have n't experienced any eye irritation ( yet ) . i am hopeful that the sensitive skin formula truly is for sensitive skin and that 's why i have had no irritation . the cream has no scent whatsoever , and i actually like a light scent in facial products , but i understand the absence of one since it is billed as for sensitive skin . on the downside , i feel that this moisturizer has caused me to break out a bit on my forehead and cheeks . i do not normally suffer from acne , but have developed some small skin colored bumps on my forehead and cheeks since beginning to use this product . i am hoping it is my skin getting used to the cream and that they will not persist each time i use this product .

i 've been eating this and and competing similar products as a part of a dietary meal plan , so i thought i 'd share my experience . i 'm not going to focus on nutritional details since that 's readily available on the package . instead i 'm focusing solely on subjective experience , and since i ordered a wide variety of similar products i 'm going to use a standard template because i 'm lazy that way . preparation : unlike the other entrees i 've been eating , this one had some assembly required . opening the package reveals a covered bowl containing a large plastic package of noodles , a smaller plastic package of teriyaki sauce , and two tiny foil packages containing dried vegetables and sesame seeds . the instructions called for putting the noodles in first , then the vegetables , then the teriyaki sauce , then two tablespoons of water , cover loosely with the lid , and microwave on high for qqq seconds . given that the vegetables were dried i opted to put them in first ( so the water would have a better chance of reaching them ) and that worked well . heating time was accurate ; qqq seconds in a qqq microwave oven on a rotating plate , followed by a one minute rest , perfectly heated the entree . observations : the vegetables are an honest - to - goodness joke . i understand that they need to be so tiny in order to properly rehydrate during preparation , but the quantity of vegetables is so tiny and their contribution to the dish is so meaningless that i do n't even really understand why they 're included in the first place . there 's maybe a tablespoon of vegetables in here and they add nothing in terms of flavor or texture and almost nothing in appearance . the teriyaki sauce is thicker than i would have preferred , and is not as strong as the teriyaki sauces you might encounter in a restaurant . i prefered this , actually , since i 'm not a big fan of strong teriyaki sauces . the noodles , of course , are the star of this dish ... but it 's a dim star . the noodles are gummy and sticky with an unpleasant rubbery feel in the mouth . the teriyaki sauce helps reduce the stickiness of the noodles but not enough . partway through the dish i added a tiny bit of sesame oil to what was left and gave it a good stir ; that helped quite a bit , though the unpleasant mouth feel remained . the sesame seeds were nothing special but did add a bit of welcome texture variation . verdict : not really digging this one and likely wo n't re - order it . the mouth feel of the noodles really spoils any hope for improvement of this dish , but i do think there is room for improvement . doubling or even tripling the vegetables would go a long way , i think , and even though this is a vegan dish i think it would be a lot more satisfying with a couple ounces of chicken in there .

although these liners work , they are n't the most appetizer way to cook and serve food . i feel like i 'm cooking in a garbage bag . still , they keep the bottom of my slow cooker clean , and that greatly accelerates clean up time . all you need to do is open up a bag , put it inside your slow cooker as close to the walls and bottom as you can , and turn the leftover material over the rim . because my crockpot has an attached lid , i tuck the plastic under the edge so it does n't get in the way . fill your pot the way you always would , and cook . when you 're done , you remove the food and throw away the bad . it 's hardly an environmentally - friendly way to cook / clean , and not everyone will feel comfortable cooking in plastic , even if that plastic is labeled as food - safe . these are best to use for recipes that tend to stick to the bottom of your slow cooker -- meats or anything that uses little liquid . given the cost , i would n't waste them on anything that can be cleaned relatively easily . -- debbie lee wesselmann

i wanted to descale my senseo machine , and the manual warned that i should not use vinegar ( which is what i have used in the past for coffee machines ) . but , the senseo brand descaler ca n't be found anywhere in the u.s. i emailed philips support , and they suggested using this brand . it 's easy to use - just dissolve one pack in a liter of water , and run it through the machine . philips recommends keeping a used coffee pod in place so it can capture any large chunks of scale and prevent the holder or frothing chamber from getting clogged up . the material is citric acid , which you can also buy in bulk at a lower price . however , i could n't find it locally , and prices online for small quantities came to about the same price as the dezcal once shipping was factored in . the only way to get it cheaper was to buy a huge container , so i opted to get the dezcal . the four ounces will last me a year ( cleaning every qqq months ) so it 's not a bad deal . urnex also makes a product called cleancaf which descales and cleans the machine . it 's cheaper , but the urnex website recommends dezcal for pod type machines such as the senseo . supposedly it 's a better product for just descaling .

if you rate this popcorn based on taste alone , it deserves a five star rating . the flavor is absolutely delicious , and one might find themselves devouring the entire bag at one sitting . now for the bad - the parent company is frito lay . this is a corporation who is guilty of poisoning its customers daily through using gmo ( genetically engineered ) corn in their products . when i first decided to purchase this popcorn , i bought it because on the bag it specifically states no artificial colors , flavors , or preservatives . what i did n't notice until later , was a line on the bag that says - partially produced with genetic engineering so basically , my take on this product is that instead of calling this frito lay popcorn , they disguise it by calling it " smartfood delight " - making us think that this is a healthier alternative by claiming that it has no artificial colors , flavors , or preservatives ... but if the popcorn itself is gmo ( genetically engineered ) corn , does anything else really matter ? there is nothing healthy about gmo foods . furthermore the companies who try to feed them to us through deceptive marketing and advertising should be punished or at the very least called out publicly and shamed for their unethical behavior . the reason i decided to give this product a qqq star rating is because i want people to read my review , and i do n't feel as if a qqq or qqq star review would get looked at , as much as a qqq star review . i also want to reiterate that the product does taste delicious , so if you are the type of person who does n't care about whether or not you were eating genetically engineered foods , then this product is a popcorn that you would buy based on taste alone . as for the rest of us , i feel like i just got bamboozled because i did n't read the bag close enough when making the original purchase . i have included two pics from a bag of their white chedder flavor to help illustrate my points .

cracklin ' oat bran cereal is a delicious treat that i have n't had for years . at local grocery stores one small box is over $ qqq , which is pretty ridiculous for cereal . when i saw it for a great price on amazon prime pantry i jumped at the chance to try my old favorite and was happy i did . cracklin ' oat bran cereal tastes like a delicious oatmeal cookie . it is satisfyingly crunchy , with an oaty , lightly sweet taste . one thing that i did not recall from eating it years ago was that it has a slightly cinnamon flavor as well . perhaps the product did not have the cinnamon flavor in prior years . i like cinnamon , but do n't always want cereal or baked goods to have a distinct cinnamon flavor , so this is something to keep in mind in case you dislike cinnamon or feel the same way i do . this cereal is so tasty that i will grab a handful and eat it plain for a snack . but it tastes even better in a bowl of milk . it is n't a low fat cereal , at qqq g of fat per serving , but it is certainly a better choice than highly processed sugary snacks , or baked goods with more fat and sugar . i find that it is somewhat rich so just a small bowl satisfies my craving for a sweet snack . i am happy to have found it available on prime pantry and will purchase it again .

i find the different options for biokleen laundry detergent a little confusing but their own website clarifies this fairly well . there are three options : qqq ) free and clear is the most popular option and contains their basic set of ingredients such as sodium carbonate , surfactant , hydrogen peroxide , etc . qqq ) citrus essence contains all of the ingredients of free and clear , plus one extra : orange peel extract . that s the only difference the scent . qqq ) premium plus contains the ingredients of free and clear , plus three extra : orange peel extract , proteases ( these are enzymes which can digest protein - based stains on clothes ) , and oxygen bleach ( which is sodium percarbonate ) . so , it comes down to this : if you do n't want the citrus scent then choose free and clear . if you do n't mind the scent then , of the remaining two options , i would recommend the premium plus . that s what i m using at the moment . a word about the extra ingredients : the proteases are produced by fermentation ( of yeast or bacteria ) and are not harmful to the environment . the oxygen bleach is sodium percarbonate , which is actually sodium carbonate and hydrogen peroxide mixed together . sodium carbonate is made from salt and limestone and is environmentally safe while hydrogen peroxide is manufactured from water and air using a catalyst ( which is recycled ) and then breaks down into water during your wash . incidentally , ewg previously gave a d grade to biokleen detergents , but they have since received more information on the formulations and have upgraded them to a for human safety . ewg are sometimes sketchy in this case they gave a d grade because the ingredient surfactant could be any one of a thousand things , some of which are harmful . now that they know the exact surfactant in the product they rate it as not harmful . the biokleen premium plus formulation is pretty similar to that of seventh generation , except that the seventh gen product has extra enzymes ( amylase for starchy stains ) . i like that company too but have n't tried their laundry detergent . i find the trend towards ultra - convenient products such as tide pods unsettling . are we really too lazy or incompetent to measure out some detergent ? the gel that encases these pods is of some concern and their use of bright dyes to make their detergent more eye - catching is also unnecessary . the water soluble gel used in pods is composed of polyvinyl alcohol , made from polymers of vinyl acetate which dow chemical states is highly toxic to fish and can cause cancer . is this risk really worth the benefit of not having to measure a scoop of detergent ? besides that , p&g do still conduct some animal testing not for tide , but i still do n't want to support them . i think biokleen is one of the most socially and environmentally responsible laundry detergents out there . they purchase wind power credits to offset their energy usage and also contribute to a river water restoration project ( and use cold water for their manufacturing process in washington ) . their ingredients and final products are not tested on animals and they use compostable or recyclable materials for the majority of their packaging . the biokleen laundry powders are extremely concentrated , reducing energy used for shipping as well as packaging materials ( which is a bare minimum of a cardboard box and plastic bag ) . one note on the product concentration some people reported their clothes smelling bad ( or about the same as pre - wash smell ) after washing , even if they use twice as much detergent . using more than the recommended amount of detergent is actually the cause of the smell , because you end up with excess surfactant left over on your clothes . you can think of this surfactant as fat , basically , which will turn rancid ( smelly ) and encourage bacterial growth . i use half a scoop in a front - loading he washing machine and have no complaints . overall , i prefer the premium plus option but have found the free and clear and citrus essence varieties to be good too . i rate all of them qqq gold stars for price and quality and qqq green stars for social and environmental responsibility .

i 've been eating this and other varieties ( and competing similar products ) as a part of a dietary meal plan , so i thought i 'd share my experience . i 'm not going to focus on nutritional details since that 's readily available on the package . instead i 'm focusing solely on subjective experience , and since i ordered like qqq different kinds i 'm going to use a standard template because i 'm lazy that way . preparation : heating time was accurate ; one minute in a qqq microwave oven on a rotating plate completely heated the entree . observations : the pasta is well cooked but not to the point of mushiness like so many shelf - stable pasta products tend to be . it is difficult to get a taste of just the pasta since there is a quite frankly astonishing amount of alfredo sauce in the bowl . after finishing the entree there was easily about six tablespoons of sauce left over . that 's not necessarily a bad thing as the flavor of the sauce is n't overpowering . it definitely lacks that pungent garlic / parmesan flavor that alfredo sauces are known for . instead i would describe it as being more of a cream sauce with a mild cheese flavor to it . i 'm used to very strong - tasting alfredo sauces ; this is not one of those . the chicken is very tender , cut into bite - sized pieces , and reasonable for a portion of this size . the chicken reminds me of the canned chicken breast that you find in the supermarket , rather than a grilled or roasted chicken that you might prepare at home . verdict : add half a cup of steamed broccoli to the bowl and it 's just about perfect . i will be reordering this in the future .

the product is called an eraser because the pad wears away as it removes marks , just like an eraser . i depend upon this and the regular magic eraser because nothing else seems to effectively handle the broad range of marks , stains , residue , etc . that this product does . my first encounter with magic erasers was when faced with crayon marks . in preparation for selling my house the realtor recommended installing new floor tile in the master bath . i was not home when the work was done but the installer had a child care problem so he brought his daughter with him and left her alone on the deck while he worked . he had given her a coloring book but not wanting to be reined in , she drew all over the decks painted railings and trim boards . he did n't notice her handiwork but when i arrived home it was quite a surprise . i phoned him and the next day he arrived to do the clean - up and all he had with him was mr. clean erasers . he was careful with the amount of pressure used and they removed the crayon but left the pain unscathed . i was convinced the rails and trim would need to be re - painted but when he was done it looked pristine . a small miracle . ever since that experience i always have them on - hand . they are particularly good on painted surfaces where it is easy to leave a mark or make a bigger mess . the wall area around light switches requires regular cleaning . what has worked for me is to use a very light touch and watch closely so as not to remove paint . they also do a good job on the glass in oven doors and removing soap scum on shower doors , gas stovetop grates and even removing coffee build - up from pots and commuter mugs . obviously , with items that are used with food , be sure to wash well after cleaning . the heavy duty erasers are great for tough tasks where the longer scrubbing time is needed because they hold together a bit longer . i make the erasers stretch by cutting the pads into smaller pieces more appropriately sized for the job . this is one of those rare products that does an exceptional job in a variety of situations for which there is no equivalent substitute .

can anyone out there explain why soup crackers go stale much faster than any other cracker on the planet ? it 's not just premium nabisco either- * all * square - shaped crackers intended for soup go bad faster than other types of crackers . i can only think of three reasons why . maybe it 's the way these crackers are made in the factory that allows staleness to creep in sooner than usual . they 're simply not meant to last long . or maybe the plastic wrapper supporting the crackers is really weak and/or thin ( recycled ) . perhaps i 'm just unlucky and there 's always a pinhole or a tear mark on the side of the plastic allowing air to get in and turn the crackers stale . or maybe it 's because i place them in the cabinet above where the stove is , and the steam from all the boiling i do rises and absorbs into the crackers . so many possibilities ! more than three ! either way when you buy a box of soup crackers , you have to use them pretty fast . like less than qqq weeks , and since each box holds qqq reams ... yeah . make sure you plan on eating a lot of soup when you buy a box of crackers !

what on earth did someone put into these to make this taste so bland ? the premise is a nice one when pieced apart : chewy , granola , dark chocolate , pomegranate . but when combined ? blech , not a fan . i mean i do n't hate them , and since i already purchased them , ill be finishing up the box , but i wo n't ever go out of my way to actually buy them . that being said , like most things , there are some good and some bad things about this bar first off , it lists organic front and center on the label . but what exactly is organic ? according to the back , everything is organically produced with the exception of vegetable glycerin , sea salt , and something called natural flavor ( vegan ) . there is a limited amount of fat ( qqq g ) , but also a limited amount of vitamins ( just qqq % calcium and qqq % iron ) . the good : -organic is displayed all over it , and to its part qqq % of the ingredients are actually organic . ( insofar as its certified by quality assurance international ) -with qqq cholesterol , it may be a good choice for someone seeking a crumbly bar , without much taste , that does nt raise cholesterol maybe for someone just seeking to fill their belly ? qqq g of protein , which is more than probably half the other granola bars on the market . the bad : -it claims its chewy , but its definitely more akin to crumbly . by simply removing the bar from the wrapper , it falls apart . -its extremely bland . i get it , it uses a bunch of healthier grains and ingredients , but as someone who organically gardens that does nt mean it has to be so flavorless and bland . -limited chocolate taste and absolutely qqq pomegranate taste . chocolate is listed as the fourth ingredient and pomegranates at the seventh . -quite simply , it tastes bland , but also a little bit stale . not a very appetizing taste . the verdict : not a good option for someone backpacking , as it crumbles at the slightly touch , so i ca nt imagine it ll hold well crammed into a backpack . i think it would prove a decent option for someone wanting to add chewiness to their cereal , if there are such people on this earth , without adding a ton of sweetness . since its not a very sweet bar , or actually all that flavorful in any way , shape , or form , it may alternatively prove to be an okay additive to muffins or cookies , if you 're on some sort of health kick and you want to add more grains to your diet .

i do n't love these as much as the cranberry almond variety , but i guess that s a matter of personal taste - if you like banana - flavored things you may love them . each packet contains three thin cookies that , combined , amount to one pretty filling serving ( qqq calories ) . the dominant flavor is banana , which never quite works for me in these bars - it tastes a little artificial and i figure i might be better off eating a real banana . with a qqq carbs to protein ratio ( qqq g carbs , qqq g sugars , qqq grams protein ) they are a little heavy on carbs and sugar , but also contain a lot of fiber ( qqq % dv ) , low sodium , and a good fat balance . the two main ingredients are whole oat flour and whole oats , so they 're heart - healthy in that sense . however , i also want to look at the social and environmental impact of this product and will give it a separate green star rating of qqq green stars . on the plus side , oats are a pretty sustainable crop they have lower needs for water , fertilizer , and tilling . unfortunately , none of the ingredients are organically grown , and if it matters to you it does also contain some gmo ingredients ( they are good enough to disclose this , and on the website they acknowledge that their oat crops are sprayed with glyphosate ) . quaker is owned by pepsico , so its necessary to take that into account when making an assessment . pepsi have been slow to improve on social and environmental issues , such as sourcing palm oil responsibly ( there s no palm oil in these quaker bars but purchasing them does still support pepsico ) . it looks like quaker have n't updated their oats and the environment page ( which deals with some of their sustainability goals ) since the last decade they are leaving that to pepsi now , i guess . pepsis corporate social responsibility report is full of vague statements for example , they are happy that their greenhouse gas emissions have remained flat for their older plants . if you look at their more detailed gri report you can see how their total ghg emissions have gone up qqq % between qqq and qqq . without going into every detail on their social and environmental impact i d say that ( tasty as these quaker bars are ) i do n't feel like supporting quaker / pepsico . besides , i m pretty sure we can make healthier , tastier and more sustainable bars at home without too much effort .
